query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
1 Contra miglior voler voler mal pugna; 2 onde contra ’l piacer mio, per piacerli, 3 trassi de l’acqua non sazia la spugna.

query.result:
4 I moved; and my leader moved along with me 5 through the expeditious places, right along the rock, 6 as one goes along a narrow wall to the battlements;
7 because the people who pour drop by drop 8 through their eyes the evil that occupies the whole world, 9 on the other side approach too close.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
25 Seguentemente intesi: «O buon Fabrizio, 26 con povertà volesti anzi virtute 27 che gran ricchezza posseder con vizio».
query.result: 25 Subsequently I heard: "O good Fabricius, 26 with poverty you preferred virtue 27 rather than possessing great wealth with vice."

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
28 Queste parole m’eran sì piaciute, 29 ch’io mi trassi oltre per aver contezza 30 di quello spirto onde parean venute.
query.result: 28 These words were so pleasing to me, 29 that I moved on to learn more 30 about the spirit from whom they seemed to come.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
31 Esso parlava ancor de la larghezza 32 che fece Niccolò a le pulcelle, 33 per condurre ad onor lor giovinezza.
query.result: 31 He was still speaking of the generosity 32 that Nicholas showed to the maidens, 33 to lead their youth to honor.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
34 «O anima che tanto ben favelle, 35 dimmi chi fosti», dissi, «e perché sola 36 tu queste degne lode rinovelle.
query.result: 34 "O soul who speaks so well, 35 tell me who you were," I said, "and why you alone 36 renew these worthy praises.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
37 Non fia sanza mercé la tua parola, 38 s’io ritorno a compiér lo cammin corto 39 di quella vita ch’al termine vola».
query.result: 37 Your words will not be without reward, 38 if I return to complete the short journey 39 of that life which flies to its end."

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
40 Ed elli: «Io ti dirò, non per conforto 41 ch’io attenda di là, ma perché tanta 42 grazia in te luce prima che sie morto.
query.result: 40 And he: "I will tell you, not for any comfort 41 that I expect from there, but because so much 42 grace shines in you before you are dead.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
43 Io fui radice de la mala pianta 44 che la terra cristiana tutta aduggia, 45 sì che buon frutto rado se ne schianta.
query.result: 43 I was the root of the evil plant 44 that overshadows all Christian land, 45 so that good fruit is rarely plucked from it.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
46 Ma se Doagio, Lilla, Guanto e Bruggia 47 potesser, tosto ne saria vendetta; 48 e io la cheggio a lui che tutto giuggia.

Please translate literally into English.
49 Chiamato fui di là Ugo Ciappetta; 50 di me son nati i Filippi e i Luigi 51 per cui novellamente è Francia retta.

Please translate literally into English.
52 Figliuol fu’ io d’un beccaio di Parigi: 53 quando li regi antichi venner meno 54 tutti, fuor ch’un renduto in panni bigi,
55 trova’mi stretto ne le mani il freno 56 del governo del regno, e tanta possa 57 di nuovo acquisto, e sì d’amici pieno,
58 ch’a la corona vedova promossa 59 la testa di mio figlio fu, dal quale 60 cominciar di costor le sacrate ossa.
query.result:
52 I was the son of a butcher of Paris: 53 when the ancient kings all came to an end, 54 except for one who was clothed in gray,
55 I found myself with the reins of government 56 of the kingdom tightly in my hands, and with so much power 57 from new acquisitions, and so full of friends,
58 that the widowed crown was raised 59 upon the head of my son, from whom 60 the sacred bones of these others began.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
61 Mentre che la gran dota provenzale 62 al sangue mio non tolse la vergogna, 63 poco valea, ma pur non facea male.
query.result: 61 As long as the great dowry of Provence 62 did not take away the shame from my bloodline, 63 it was worth little, but still did no harm.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
64 Lì cominciò con forza e con menzogna 65 la sua rapina; e poscia, per ammenda, 66 Pontì e Normandia prese e Guascogna.
query.result: 64 There it began with force and with deceit 65 its plundering; and then, as amends, 66 it took Ponthieu and Normandy and Gascony.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
67 Carlo venne in Italia e, per ammenda, 68 vittima fé di Curradino; e poi 69 ripinse al ciel Tommaso, per ammenda.
query.result: 67 Charles came to Italy and, as amends, 68 made Conradin his victim; and then 69 he thrust Thomas back to Heaven, as amends.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
70 Tempo vegg’ io, non molto dopo ancoi, 71 che tragge un altro Carlo fuor di Francia, 72 per far conoscer meglio e sé e ’ suoi.
query.result: 70 I see a time, not long from now, 71 that brings forth another Charles from France, 72 to make himself and his followers better known.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
73 Sanz’ arme n’esce e solo con la lancia 74 con la qual giostrò Giuda, e quella ponta 75 sì, ch’a Fiorenza fa scoppiar la pancia.
query.result: 73 He goes forth without arms and only with the lance 74 with which Judas jousted, and he thrusts it so 75 that he makes Florence burst at the belly.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
76 Quindi non terra, ma peccato e onta 77 guadagnerà, per sé tanto più grave, 78 quanto più lieve simil danno conta.
query.result: 76 From this he will gain not land, but sin and shame, 77 all the more serious for him 78 the more lightly he counts such harm.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
79 L’altro, che già uscì preso di nave, 80 veggio vender sua figlia e patteggiarne 81 come fanno i corsar de l’altre schiave.
query.result: 79 The other, who once emerged captured from a ship, 80 I see selling his daughter and bargaining for her 81 as the pirates do for their other slaves.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
82 O avarizia, che puoi tu più farne, 83 poscia c’ha’ il mio sangue a te sì tratto, 84 che non si cura de la propria carne?
85 Perché men paia il mal futuro e ’l fatto, 86 veggio in Alagna intrar lo fiordaliso, 87 e nel vicario suo Cristo esser catto.
query.result:
82 O avarice, what more can you do to us, 83 since you have drawn my blood to you so much 84 that it does not care for its own flesh?
85 To make the evil to come and the evil done seem less, 86 I see the fleur-de-lis enter Anagni, 87 and Christ being held captive in his vicar.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
88 Veggiolo un’altra volta esser deriso; 89 veggio rinovellar l’aceto e ’l fiele, 90 e tra vivi ladroni esser anciso.

Please translate literally into English.
91 Veggio il novo Pilato sì crudele, 92 che ciò nol sazia, ma sanza decreto 93 portar nel Tempio le cupide vele.
query.result: 91 I see the new Pilate so cruel 92 that this does not satisfy him, but without decree 93 he carries the greedy sails into the Temple.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
94 O Segnor mio, quando sarò io lieto 95 a veder la vendetta che, nascosa, 96 fa dolce l’ira tua nel tuo secreto?
97 Ciò ch’io dicea di quell’ unica sposa 98 de lo Spirito Santo e che ti fece 99 verso me volger per alcuna chiosa,
100 tanto è risposto a tutte nostre prece 101 quanto ’l dì dura; ma com’ el s’annotta, 102 contrario suon prendemo in quella vece.
query.result:
94 O my Lord, when will I be glad 95 to see the vengeance that, hidden, 96 makes Your wrath sweet in Your secret?
97 What I said about that unique bride 98 of the Holy Spirit, who made You 99 turn to me for some explanation,
100 is answered to all our prayers 101 as long as the day lasts; but when night falls, 102 we take up the opposite sound instead.

103 We were repeating about Pygmalion then, 104 whom his greedy desire for gold made 105 a traitor, a thief, and a parricide;
106 and the misery of the miserly Midas, 107 who followed his greedy request, 108 for which one must always laugh.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
109 Del folle Acàn ciascun poi si ricorda, 110 come furò le spoglie, sì che l’ira 111 di Iosüè qui par ch’ancor lo morda.
query.result: 109 Then everyone remembers the foolish Achan, 110 how he stole the spoils, so that the wrath 111 of Joshua here seems to still bite him.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
118 Talor parla l’uno alto e l’altro basso, 119 secondo l’affezion ch’ad ir ci sprona 120 ora a maggiore e ora a minor passo:
121 però al ben che ’l dì ci si ragiona, 122 dianzi non era io sol; ma qui da presso 123 non alzava la voce altra persona».
query.result:
118 Sometimes one speaks loudly and the other softly, 119 according to the passion that spurs us to anger, 120 now at a faster and now at a slower pace:
121 therefore, in the good that is spoken of during the day, 122 I was not alone just now; but here nearby 123 no other person raised his voice».

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
124 Noi eravam partiti già da esso, 125 e brigavam di soverchiar la strada 126 tanto quanto al poder n’era permesso,
127 quand’ io senti’, come cosa che cada, 128 tremar lo monte; onde mi prese un gelo 129 qual prender suol colui ch’a morte vada.
query.result:
124 We had already departed from him, 125 and we were striving to cover as much ground 126 as our strength allowed,
127 when I felt the mountain tremble, like something falling; 128 whereupon a chill came over me, 129 such as usually seizes one who is going to his death.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
130 Certo non si scoteo sì forte Delo, 131 pria che Latona in lei facesse ’l nido 132 a parturir li due occhi del cielo.
query.result: 130 Surely Delos did not shake so violently, 131 before Latona made her nest there 132 to give birth to the two eyes of heaven.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
133 Poi cominciò da tutte parti un grido 134 tal, che ’l maestro inverso me si feo, 135 dicendo: «Non dubbiar, mentr’ io ti guido».
query.result: 133 Then from all sides a cry began, 134 such that my master turned to me, 135 saying: "Do not fear, while I am guiding you."

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
136 ‘Glorïa in excelsis’ tutti ‘Deo’ 137 dicean, per quel ch’io da’ vicin compresi, 138 onde intender lo grido si poteo.
query.result: 136 "Gloria in excelsis" all said "Deo", 137 from what I understood from those nearby, 138 from which the cry could be understood.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
139 No’ istavamo immobili e sospesi 140 come i pastor che prima udir quel canto, 141 fin che ’l tremar cessò ed el compiési.
query.result: 139 We stood still and suspended, 140 like the shepherds who first heard that song, 141 until the trembling ceased and it was completed.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
142 Poi ripigliammo nostro cammin santo, 143 guardando l’ombre che giacean per terra, 144 tornate già in su l’usato pianto.
query.result: 142 Then we resumed our holy journey, 143 looking at the shades that lay on the ground, 144 already returned to their accustomed weeping.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
145 Nulla ignoranza mai con tanta guerra 146 mi fé desideroso di sapere, 147 se la memoria mia in ciò non erra,
148 quanta pareami allor, pensando, avere; 149 né per la fretta dimandare er’ oso, 150 né per me lì potea cosa vedere:
151 così m’andava timido e pensoso.
query.result:
145 Never did any ignorance with such force 146 make me desirous of knowing, 147 if my memory does not err in this,
148 as I seemed to have then, thinking about it; 149 nor did I dare to ask because of the haste, 150 nor could I see anything there for myself:
151 thus I went on, timid and thoughtful.
